variant.question:
What is the Trip Fuel? Given
 Temperature ISA +15° C
 Brake release mass 62 000 kg
 Trip time 5 hrs 20 min

For this question consider the Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.5.1 En-route Climb tables.
Which statement is INCORRECT concerning climb data?

options.text:
The values for fuel used and time taken do not include
take-off and acceleration

The correct table to use is dictated by Temperature
condition

The values for fuel used and time taken include take-off
and acceleration

Fuel adjustments can be made for take-off from high
elevation airports

variant.question: The Trip fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight must consider....

options.text: The expected departure and arrival routing
fuel for 30 minutes holding in 1500 ft at the destination
fuel up to the end of the missed approach
the required fuel for an APU during the whole operation

variant.question:
(Refer to the image or Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.3.5) 
For a flight of 3500 ground nautical miles, the following apply: 
Tail wind component: 50 kt 
Temperature: ISA +10°C 
Brake release mass: 65000 kg 
The (a) trip fuel and (b) trip time respectively are:

Given the following information, for a Commercial Air Transport operation, what is the Trip Fuel?

Pressure altitude: 32000 ftCruise procedure: Long rangeGround distance: 300 NMHWC: 25 ktOAT: ISAMass at start: 40000 kg
Trip fuel consists of fuel for:

options.text: Take-off, Climb, Cruise, Descent, Approach, Landing
Take-off, Climb, Cruise, Approach, divert to alternate
Taxy, Take-off, Climb, Cruise, Descent, Approach, Landing

variant.question: What is trip fuel?

options.text: TOM - DOM - traffic load - final reserve fuel - alternate/additional fuel - contingency fuel.
TOM - DOM - traffic load + final reserve fuel + alternate/additional fuel + contingency fuel.
TOM + DOM + traffic load - final reserve fuel – alternate/additional fuel – contingency fuel – taxi fuel.
TOM - DOM - traffic load - final reserve fuel - alternate/additional fuel - contingency fuel - taxi fuel.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 033-147.
What amount of fuel are you going to enter in BOX A (Trip Fuel)?
The trip fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight should include...

(Refer to the image or Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.3.)
The following apply:  Temperature: ISA +15°C  Brake release mass: 62000 kg 
Trip time: 5 h 20 min 
What is the trip fuel?
Which of the following is covered by the trip fuel?

options.text: Required fuel for the APU during the whole operation.
Fuel up to the end of the missed approach procedure.
Fuel for 30 minutes holding in 1 500 ft above the destination aerodrome.

variant.question: What amount of fuel should be entered in the TRIP line (Box A)?
What amount of fuel should be entered in the TRIP line (Box A)?

Refer to figure 033-23.
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:


- Take-off mass: 168 500 kg
- Cruise level: FL 370
- Cruise regime:   Long Range (LRC)
- Flight leg ground distance: 2 000 NM
- Wind component: 30 kts tail
- "Total anti-ice" setting: ON
- Taxi fuel: 500 kg
- Final reserve: 2 000 kg
- Notes:  
  </tr>
  <tr> 
   <div>1) Ignore contingency and alternate fuel.
   2) Do not apply climb and descent fuel corrections.
   

The prescribed quantity of Trip Fuel for the flight leg is:

Refer to figure 033-22.
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:


- Take-off mass: 210 500 kg
- Cruise level: FL 330
- Cruise regime:   Long Range (LRC)
- Flight leg ground distance: 2 500 NM
- Wind component: 70 kt tail
- "Total anti-ice" setting: ON
- Taxi fuel: 500 kg
- Final reserve: 2 400 kg
- Notes:  
  </tr>
  <tr> 
   <div>1) Ignore contingency and alternate fuel.
   2) Do not apply climb and descent fuel corrections.
   

The quantity of fuel that must be loaded at the parking area is:

Refer to figures 033-28, 033-32 and 033-93.
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:


- Ground distance: 4 000 NM
- Cruise level:   FL370
- Cruise speed: Long Range Cruise
- Conditions:   50 kt headwind / ISA
- Centre of Gravity (CG): 37 %
- Pack Flow: LOW (LO)
- Anti Ice: OFF
- Reference Landing Mass: 140 000 kg
- Taxi Fuel: 500 kg
- Final Reserve Fuel: 2 400 kg

The fuel quantity which must be loaded on board the aircraft, excluding any contingency fuel, is:

Refer to figure 033-24.
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:


- Cruise level: FL370
- Cruise regime:   Long Range (LRC)
- Mass at brake release: 204 500 kg
- Flight leg ground distance: 2 000 NM
- Temperatures: ISA
- Wind component: 70 kt head
- "Total anti-ice" setting:  ON (entire flight)

No requested climb and descent correction of the fuel consumption. The fuel required from take-off to landing is:

Refer to figure 033-24.
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:


- Cruise level: FL370
- Cruise regime:   Long Range (LRC)
- Mass at brake release: 212 800 kg
- Flight leg ground distance:   2 500 NM
- Wind component: 30 kt head
- Temperatures: ISA
- CG: 37 %
- "Total anti-ice" setting:  ON (entire flight)

No requested climb and descent correction of the fuel consumption. The fuel consumption from take-off to landing is:

Refer to figure or CAP file 4.3.1.a. 
 Using the simplified Flight Planning Charts, given the following information:Trip distance: 300 NM 
 ISA deviation: +10ºC 
 Average wind: 75 kt headwind 
 Pressure altitude: 29 000 ft 
 Estimated Landing Weight: 40 000 kg 
 Long Range CruiseDetermine the fuel required.
Which of the statements correctly completes the description of Trip Fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight? Trip Fuel is the amount of fuel required from

options.text: take-off to landing at the destination.
take-off to landing at the destination, and includes contingency fuel.
the parking position to landing at the destination.
take-off to landing at the alternate.

variant.question:
A Commercial Air Transport flight is planned without an alternate aerodrome. The Trip Fuel must include fuel for which of the following?
1. Taxi, take-off and climb
2. Cruise and step climb/descent
3. Descent, approach and landing
4. Contingencies and missed approach
5. Holding for 15 minutes at 1500 ft above destination aerodrome elevation

A Commercial Air Transport flight is planned without an alternate aerodrome
The Trip Fuel must include fuel for which of the following? 
1. Taxi, take-off and climb 
2. Cruise and step climb/descent 
3. Descent, approach and landing 
4. Contingencies and missed approach 
5. Holding for 15 minutes at 1500 ft above destination aerodrome elevation?
The Trip Fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight includes fuel from

options.text: take-off to landing including the expected departure, arrival, approach, climb and descent.
the end of the departure route to the beginning of the arrival route, including the climb and descent.
top of climb to top of descent, excluding step climbs and descents during the cruise.
the block position to landing including the expected departure, arrival, approach, climb and descent.

variant.question:
Given the following information, what is the Trip Fuel for the planned Commercial Air Transport flight under VFR?

Power setting: Full throttle / 2500 RPMGS: 130 ktTrip distance from TOC: 190 NMCruising altitude: 8000 ftOAT: ISAAdditional fuel for climb: 3.2 galAdditional fuel for approach: 10 minutes at cruise fuel flow

(Refer to the image or Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.3.5) 
The following apply: Tail wind component: 10kt   Temperature: ISA +10°C 
Brake release mass: 63000 kg    Trip fuel available: 20000 kg 
What is the maximum possible trip distance?
In order to get alternate fuel and time, the twin-jet aeroplane operations manual graph shall be entered with:

options.text: Landing mass at alternate, distance (NM), wind component.
Flight time, wind component, landing mass at alternate.
Zero Fuel Mass, still air distance, wind component.
Distance (NM), wind component, Zero Fuel Mass.

variant.question:
Which of the following are included in Trip Fuel:
1.  Taxy, Take Off, Climb
2.  Take Off, Step Climb, Cruise
3.  Descent, Approach, Missed Approach
4.  Hold 15 min ar 1500ft AAL
5.  Descent, Approach, Landing

Given the following information, for a Commercial Air Transport operation, how much Trip Fuel is needed for this segment?
Gross mass : 40000 kgPressure altitude: 32000 ftCruise procedure: Longe rangeSegment distance : 350 Nautical Air Miles (NAM)HWC : 25 ktOAT : -59° C

Using Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.3.6
 
  In order to get alternate fuel and time, the twin-jet aeroplane operations manual graph shall be entered with

options.text: Landing mass at alternate, distance (NM), wind component.
Distance (NM), wind component, Zero Fuel Mass.
Zero Fuel Mass, still air distance, wind component.
Flight time, wind component, landing mass at alternate.

options.text: Fuel for take-off, climb, cruise, descent, approach and landing.
Fuel for climb, cruise and descent.
Fuel for take-off, climb, cruise, descent approach and landing, and a missed approach.
Fuel from top of climb to top of descent.

variant.question:

Fuel over NANEV: 650 kgTAS: 200 ktWind component: +17 ktFuel flow: 180 kg/h

Trim tank: FullOuter tanks: FullInner tanks: 15 000 kg each
